content: The "Secure America Act of 2005" is the short title of the Act which includes amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act. The table of contents outlines the sections of the Act. The "Secure America Act of 2005" includes amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act, with sections on expedited removal, increased criminal sentences for alien smuggling, enhanced penalties for armed offenses, use of military to secure the border, mandatory sentencing for reentering aliens, penalties for countries not accepting nationals, and the creation of the Bureau of Immigration Enforcement. The "Secure America Act of 2005" amends Section 235(b)(1)(A)(iii) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, giving the Secretary of Homeland Security authority over certain aliens apprehended near the US border within 14 days of entry. The "Secure America Act of 2005" expands the authority of the Secretary of Homeland Security over aliens apprehended near the US border within 14 days of entry. Amendments include exceptions for aliens apprehended at or between land border ports of entry, with an effective date upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. INCREASED CRIMINAL SENTENCES AND FINES FOR ALIEN SMUGGLING. The United States Sentencing Commission will increase minimum prison terms for smuggling, transporting, harboring, or inducing aliens under the Immigration and Nationality Act, ranging from 30 to 111 months based on the number of aliens involved. Additionally, fines will be raised for each offense. The United States Sentencing Commission will increase minimum prison terms and fines for offenses related to smuggling, transporting, harboring, or inducing aliens under the Immigration and Nationality Act. This includes raising fines to the greater of $25,000 per alien or 3 times the compensation received, increasing sentencing enhancements for causing bodily injury, and aligning offense levels for actions causing death with involuntary manslaughter charges. Additionally, penalties for corporations or business entities will also be enhanced. The United States Sentencing Commission will increase fines for corporations benefiting from offenses related to alien employment to $50,000 per alien. An exception is made for offenses involving only the defendant's spouse or child. The Commission must implement these changes within 6 months of the Act's enactment. Additionally, criminal penalties under Section 274(a) will be amended to increase the maximum prison term to 15 years. The maximum prison term under Section 274(a) will be increased to 15 years, fines for corporations benefiting from alien employment offenses will be raised to $50,000 per alien, with exceptions for offenses involving the defendant's spouse or child. Other penalties will also be increased, with imprisonment ranging from 5 to 25 years. The prison term under Section 274(a) will be increased to 15 years, fines for corporations benefiting from alien employment offenses will be raised to $50,000 per alien, with exceptions for offenses involving the defendant's spouse or child. Penalties for third or subsequent offenses will result in fines and imprisonment ranging from 5 to 15 years. The prison term under Section 274(a) will be increased to 15 years, fines for corporations benefiting from alien employment offenses will be raised to $50,000 per alien, with exceptions for offenses involving the defendant's spouse or child. Penalties for third or subsequent offenses will result in fines and imprisonment ranging from 5 to 15 years. The amendments made by subsection (d) shall take effect on the date of enactment of this Act and shall apply to offenses committed after such date, increasing the prison term from 10 to 20 years. SEC. 4. ENHANCED PENALTIES FOR PERSONS COMMITTING OFFENSES WHILE ARMED. Section 924(c)(1) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include violations of section 274(a)(1)(A) of the Immigration and Nationality Act as offenses. The amendments take effect upon the enactment of this Act and apply to offenses committed after that date. SEC. 5. Use of Army and Air Force to secure the border by preventing unauthorized entry of aliens, terrorists, and drug smugglers. Amendment to Section 1385 of title 18, United States Code. Effective upon enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. Mandatory sentencing ranges for reentering aliens. Mandatory sentencing ranges for reentering aliens under Section 276 (8 U.S.C. 1326) are amended to increase imprisonment terms. Subsection (a) now requires imprisonment for a term of not less than 1 year and not more than 2 years. Subsection (b) specifies imprisonment for a term of not less than 5 years and not more than 10 years for paragraph (1), not less than 10 years and not more than 20 years for paragraph (2), and not less than 20 years for paragraph (4). The amendment to Section 277 (8 U.S.C. 1327) increases mandatory sentencing ranges for aiding or assisting reentering aliens. Any person aiding or assisting in violation of section 276(b) may face a fine, imprisonment for a term imposed under paragraph (2), or both. The term of imprisonment imposed shall be not less than 5 years and not more than 10 years. The term of imprisonment for aiding or assisting reentering aliens shall be within the range specified in section 276(b). The amendments made by this section are effective upon enactment and apply to sentences entered on or after that date. SEC. 7. PENALTY FOR COUNTRIES THAT DO NOT ACCEPT RETURN OF NATIONALS. Section 243(d) (8 U.S.C. 1253(d)) is amended to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to deny admission to citizens of foreign countries that have refused to accept their citizens who have been ordered removed from the United States. The amendments made by subsection (a) are effective on the date of enactment of this Act, until the country accepts the alien that was ordered removed. SEC. 8. BUREAU OF IMMIGRATION ENFORCEMENT. Amends Section 442 of Public Law 107-296 to establish the Bureau of Immigration Enforcement. The Bureau of Immigration Enforcement is established within the Department of Homeland Security, with specific functions outlined in section 441. The head of the Bureau, the Assistant Secretary, must have at least 5 years of professional experience in immigration law enforcement. The Bureau of Immigration Enforcement, established within the Department of Homeland Security, requires the Assistant Secretary to have 5 years of experience in immigration law enforcement and 5 years of management experience. Amendments include changing references from "Bureau of Border Security" to "Bureau of Immigration Enforcement" in various subsections. In subsection (a)(5), the Assistant Secretary of the Bureau of Border Security is replaced with the Assistant Secretary of the Bureau of Immigration Enforcement. Subsection (b) and (c) also replace references to the Bureau of Border Security with the Bureau of Immigration Enforcement. Sections 443, 444, 451, and 471 of the Public Law are amended accordingly. The authority provided by section 1502 may not be used to add functions of the Bureau of Immigration Enforcement not listed in section 441.
